Mapping UI Elements

Buttons

Example Description Usage

View in context

 Map Buttons

When buttons are positioned directly over a map, the class btn-map should be added in addition to the desired Bootstrap classes. The btn-map adds a subtle drop shadow to the button to make it stand out on the map.

Buttons that contain only an icon should be rendered square. To achieve this include the class btn-map-icon

Do not apply this class to buttons that are displayed within another UI element that is on the map. E.g. Do not add it to buttons that are inside a pop-over.

<a class="btn btn-map" href="">Link</a>
<button class="btn btn-map" type="submit">Button</button>

Follow the standard button guidelines for when to use buttons and the usage of the supplementary classes.
Map Button Groups

As with individual buttons, button groups that are placed directly over the map should have the class btn-map added. It will add a subtle shadow to make the button group more visible over the map.

<div class="btn-group btn-map">
  <button class="btn">Left</button>
  <button class="btn">Middle</button>
  <button class="btn">Right</button>
</div>

Only add the btn-map class to the btn-group container, not to every button in the group.

Markers

Example
   Normal   Small  With icon  Alert     Ok    Warning Highlight  Hover  Selected
  Basic Application States UI States
Default
Basic, reusable marker type for the primary POIs in an application.
E.g. asset, train.
Moving
Used for items that are moving.
E.g. ship in transit.
Info
Used for data and information.
E.g. Buildings, and other items which are secondary in the app.
Virtual/Temporary
Used for items that are transient or temporary.
E.g. search result, route start or end point.
Notification
Used for notifications about things that do not normally have a marker.
E.g. showing a break in a water line.

View default marker with icon in context

View more example markers on the map
Stateful Markers for indicating points of interest on the map

Markers are used to display geolocation points on the map. This is an initial implementation of the Marker component which will continue to grow in the number of implemented marker types and functionality.

At a minimum, the map-core and map-marker components are required to show markers on the map. Unlike basic markers on consumer maps the focus is on binding a set of data rather than creating and managing individual markers. Once the map is initialised a set of GeoJSON data can be bound to the marker component. The API to the marker component is markers.addMarkers(data, map, popoverOptions,layerName, indexOptions);. Only the first two parameters are required.

Note: see Map Popovers for details on how to use the popoverOptions parameter to attach popovers to map markers.

Script:

require(['jquery', 'map-core', 'map-markers'], function($,Mapping,markers){

  $.subscribe('mapInitialised', function(mapName, map){
    $.ajax({
      url : '../../data/basic-marker-example.json',
      async : true, dataType: "json"
    })
    .done(function(data) {
      markers.addMarkers(data,map);
    });
  });

  $(".map").initializeMap();

});

The Marker component uses the D3 Geo Paths to bind to and render the markers and so the data needs to be in GeoJSON format. Currently the Marker component only handles Point features. A metadata object may be provided to define the marker appearance, and a properties object can be used to contain attribute data. A unique feature Id id may be provided but is not required.

Note: The Id is used for indexing the data and as an identifier for the DOM element, so if it is supplied it must be unique.

Note: There are four optional metadata properties that control how the markers are rendered. See table below and the sample GeoJSON.

Metadata Properties:

Name type default description
type string "default" This determines the shape of the marker. Options are: default, virtual, moving, info, notification, myposition. The -mini suffix can be added to show a smaller version of the marker without an icon.
state css class "" The state class determines the color of the marker following the same approach as IIDX labels and buttons; default, warning, important, success, highlight.
icon font-awesome Unicode character "" It is possible to place a Font-awesome icon inside a large marker by passing in the icon's unicode character, e.g. "\uf0d1" shows a truck icon.
iconPos {x,y} coordinate object {} A pixel offset coordinate for the icon, used to centre it in the marker.

GeoJSON example:

{"type":"FeatureCollection",
  "features":[
    {"type":"Feature",
      "properties":{"addressLine1":"1050 Crow Canyon Road","addressLine2":"San Ramon (CA)","zip":"12346", "tel": "(0123) 45678"},
      "geometry":{"type":"Point","coordinates":[-121.975193,37.777120]},
      "metadata":{"type":"virtual","state":"default", "icon":"\uf05a", "iconPos":{"x":-6.5, "y": -18.5}}},
    {"type":"Feature",
      "properties":{"addressLine1":"1 Alcosta Blvd","addressLine2":"San Ramon (CA)","zip":"12345", "tel": "(0123) 45678"},
      "geometry":{"type":"Point","coordinates":[-121.964421,37.781428]},
      "metadata":{"type":"virtual-mini", "state": "warning"}},
    {"type":"Feature",
      "properties":{"addressLine1":"105 Deerwood Road","addressLine2":"San Ramon (CA)","zip":"12347", "tel": "(0123) 45678"},
      "geometry":{"type":"Point","coordinates":[-121.984806,37.778816]},
      "metadata":{"type":"myposition"}, "icon":"\uf0d1", "iconPos":{"x":-7.25, "y": 4.5}},
  ]
}
Script Requirements:
  • map-markers
Indexing asset data using the marker component

Asset data in the properties object may be indexed for search by providing the indexOptions parameter to the marker component. See Object Search for more information

Script:

Note: use of the popoverOptions parameter is described in Map Popovers.

Note: the layerName parameter determines the name of the layer shown in the Layer Control.

var indexOptions =  { indexAttribs : [ "Leader" ],
                      secondaryAttribs : [ "Type", "Number" ],
                      facet : "Status" };

markers.addMarkers(data, olMap, popoverOptions, 'Crews', indexOptions);

GeoJSON example:

{
  "type": "FeatureCollection",
      "features": [
          {"type": "Feature",
              "properties": {"Number" : 0,"Leader": "Michael Tasker","Type": "Investigation","Status": "On Duty"},
              "geometry": {"type": "Point","coordinates": [-76.19806,42.60412]}},
          {"type": "Feature",
              "properties": {"Number" : 1,"Leader" : "Micheal Tasker","Type" : "Investigation","Status" : "On Duty"},
              "geometry": {"type": "Point","coordinates": [-76.19806,42.60412]}}
      ]
}

The following table describes the attributes of the indexOptions object.

Options:

Name type default description
indexAttribs string array null This is the only required attribute for indexing. It defines which fields in the GeoJSON properties object will be added to the index. If more than one is defined, the field values will be concatenated to provide the typeahead results when using the Asset Search component.
secondaryAttribs string array null This attribute determines which field values will be shown as secondary attributes in the faceted search typeahed results. It will have no effect for non-faceted search. As with indexAttribs, multiple field values will be concatenated for diplay in the result typeahead.
facet string null This determines which field will be used as the facet subdivision in faceted search typeahead results. It will have no effect for non-faceted search.

View a faceted asset search example, combined with Google address search

View a non-faceted asset search example

Clusters

Example Description Usage
View simple clustering in context Simple Marker Clustering

OpenLayers provides a simple clustering API to support the visualization of many markers that may overlap on the map. As users zoom in and out of the map, clusters will recalculate and disperse into markers when there is adequate space between them.

Markup: 

<div class="map" data-map-name="default">

Script: 

require(['jquery', 'map-core', 'map-cluster'], function($, Mapping, cluster){
  $.subscribe('mapInitialised', function(mapName, olMap){
    $.ajax({
      url : '../../data/GeoJSON_example.json',
      async : true, dataType: "json"
    }).done(function(data) {
      cluster.addClusters(data,olMap);
    });
  });
  $(".map").initializeMap();
});

Script Requirements:
  • map-cluster
